div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
CHristian Reader, if thou wouldst be strengthned in thy faith, and be able (by the grace of God) to resist Satan when hee shall put into thy heart any fearefull thought tending to despaire, have this little Booke alwaies in thy pocket, to read at leasure-times, and marke wel what thou readest, concerning the Covenant
of grace and seales thereof, which you shall find plainely opened, and pray to God for an understanding heart.

closer.signed: Thine in the Lord JESVS, L. H.

div.head: THE COVENANT of Grace plainely opened, by way of Question and Answer.
div.p: Q. 1. SIR, I pray you, shew mee what the Covenant of Grace is, that God hath made with his elect children?

A. That you may the better understand, what the Covenant or grace is
and upon what occasion God did make it, I hold it needefull, that I speake first, of the Creation of Adam and Evah, and of their fall from that good estate, wherin they were created, and of the wrath and cu se of God that they brought upon them selves and upon all mankind.
Q. 2. Doe so, I pray you, and first tell mee, to whom did God speake, when hee said, Let us make man?

A. There was then no creature for God to speak unto: The meaning is,
that the holy Trinitie did then consult about the making of man, that he might excel all worldly creatures.
Q. 3. Wherein was man made to excell all creatures?
A. In knowledge, in holinesse, and in righteousnesse, after the Image of God, Col. 3.18. Ephes. 4.24.
Q. 4. Whereof did God make Adam?
A. God made his body of the dust of the earth, and breathed into him the breath of life, Gen. 2.7.
Qu. 5. What is meant by the breath of life?
A. By the breath of life, is meant the soule.
Qu. 6. Why is the soule called the breath of life?
A. It is called the breath or spirit of life, because it is an everlasting spirit that giveth life to every part of the body.
Q. 7. Whereof was Evah made?
A. She was made of one of Adams ribbes.
Q. 8. When was she made?

A. When God brought
the fowles of the ayre, and beasts of the field to Adam, to see how hee would name them, they were brought by couples, male and female, so as every male had a female, to be an helpe fit for it, onely Adam was alone; then God seeing that every male had an help fit for it, and that among them all he found not an helpe meete for Adam; therefore God caused an heavie sleep to come upon Adam, and then took out one of his ribbes, and thereof made Evah, and brought her to him, and bestowed her upon him
in marriage, Gen. 2.20, 21, 22.
Q. 9. What did God for them in their marriage?

A. As in their creation God blessed them with spirituall blessings of knowledge, holinesses & righteousnesse, so in their marriage God blessed them with temporall blessings; as first, with power to bring forth children: Secondly, with power to till and to subdue the earth, that is, to build and plant in it: Thirdly, with power and dominion over the fowls
of the ayre, the fishes of the Sea, the beasts of the field, and over every thing that creepeth and moveth on the earth.

Also, God did make a legall covenant with them, and in them with all mankinde, wherein he did promise and grant, that they & all mankind should continue in his love and favour, so long as they continued in perfect obedience unto his Law.
Qu. 10. What dwelling place did God provide for them?

A. God did provide a
sweet dwelling place for them, in a pleasant Garden, called Paradise, and as soon as they were setled in Paradise, God left them to themselves with free will to do what pleased them; even as a loving father, after he hath bestowed his children in marriage, and given them their portions, doth then leave them to themselvs, to see what course they will take.

Qu. 11. What assurance did God make thē of their continuance in his love and favour, and in all worldly happinesse
so long as they did continue in perfect obedience unto his Law?

A. God did plant a Tree in the midst of the Garden, called the Tree of life, to be a Sacrament, to strengthen their faith in the Covenant, and continuance in his love and favour, and all worldly happinesse, so long as they continued in perfect obedience to all his Commandements.
Qu. 12. What tryall did God make of their obedience?

A. For tryall of their obedience, God planted
another Tree, called the Tree of knowledge of good and evill, and gave them charge not to eate thereof, upon paine of death.
Qu. 13. How came they to eate of the fruit of the Tree?

A. They were no sooner left to themselves, but the Devill (envying their happinesse) came cunningly in the Serpent, and tempted Evah, and drew her to eate, and to give to her husband, and to draw him to eate, and so to breake the Covenant, and make way for
the wrath and curse of God to come upon them, and upon all mankinde, because all were then, in them, and were all corrupted and made sinfull, by their being in them.
Qu. 14. How could all mankind be in them?

A. I will make it plaine unto you by a familiar comparison: take the kernell of an Apple, and set it where it may grow to be a tree, bearing fruit; that tree will bring forth many apples, and every apple many kernels, which if they also be set where they may
grow to be trees, bearing fruit, will bring forth many apples, and every apple many kernels; yea, innumerable, which though in time they com to be innumerable, were all at first, in, and come out of one kernell: even so mankind, though now innumerable, were all at first in Adam and Evah.
Q. 15. It is written, that the eyes of Adam & Evah were opened, as soone as they had eaten: were they blinde till then?

A. No, the meaning is, that as soone as they
both had eaten, God did take from them all their glory and happinesse, wherein they lived, and left them to themselves, naked, in shame and sorrow, ready to perish.
Q. 16. It is written, that they heard the voyce of the Lord walking in the Garden, in the coole of the day: what is meant by the walking of the voyce?

A. The meaning is, that the voyce seemed, at the first, to be farre off, and to come neerer and neerer, as thunder which is called the voyce of the
Lord, Psal. 29. doth somtimes begin farre off, and commeth neerer and neerer.
Q. 17. What did they when they heard the voyce of the Lord?

A. They hid themselves among the Trees, which sheweth, that the natur of sin is to wound the conscience, and that a wounded conscience will accuse and torment a man with shame and feare, and cause him to despaire and flee from God.

Q. 18. What did God to them, when they hid
themselves?
A. God called to Adam, saying, where art thou?
Q. 19. What answer did Adam make?

A. Adam answered, saying, I heard thy voice in the garden, and was afraid because I was naked therefore I hid my selfe, whereupon God said unto him, who told thee that thou was naked? Hast thou eaten of the Tree, whereof I commanded thee that thou shouldst not eate?
Q. 20. What answer did Adam make?
A. Adam answered, saying, the woman that thou gavest to be with me, shee gave me, and I did eate.
Q. 21. What said God to the woman?
A. God asked her why she had done so.
Q. 22. What answer did she make?
A. She (to excuse her selfe) laid all the fault upon the Serpent, saying, the Serpent beguiled me, and I did eate.
Q. 23. What doe you observe in their answers.

A. That such as are void of the feare of God,
and of a good conscience, will smoulder and hide their faults, and excuse themselves by accusing others.
Q 24. What said God to the Serpent?

A. God did not vouchsafe to speake to the Serpent, but did presently lay his curse upon her, saying, because thou hast done this, cursed art thou above all Cattell; upon thy belly shalt thou goe, and dust shalt thou eate all the dayes of thy life: I will also put enmity betweene thee and the woman, and betweene thy
seed and her seed; it shall breake thine head, and thou shalt bruise his heele.
Q. 25. What is the meaning of these words, I will put enmity betweene thee and the woman, and betweene thy seed and her seed, it shall breake thine head and thou shalt bruise his heel?
A. They are to bee taken two wayes; first, as they were spoken to the Serpent; secondly, as they were spoken to the Divell in the Serpent.

As they were spoken to the Serpent, they doe
containe a threatning, to put enmitie, that is, unreconcileable hatred betweene the Serpent and Evah, and between both their seeds.
Q. 26. What is meant by the seede of the Serpent?
A. Adders and snakes.
Q. 27. What is meant by the seede of the woman?
A. All mankind.

The truth of this is seene daily, when a man commeth on the sudden, where an Adder or snake is, they will startle and run away one from another,
and the man, if hee have any thing in his hand, will strike at the head, to breake it; and the Adder or Snake when it seeth that it cannot save it selfe by creeping away, will turne againe, and doe what it can to sting the man in the heel, or some where in the foot or legge, because it can reach no higher.

Q. 28. What is the meaning of them, as they were spoken to the Divell in the Serpent; and first tell me what is meant by the Serpent, and by the seed of the Serpent,
and by the woman, and by seed of the woman?

A. By the Serpent is meant the Divell; by the seede of the Serpent is meant the wicked that live and dye in their sins, without true faith and repentance. By the woman, is meant Evah; by the seed of the woman, is meant our Savior Christ, and those whom GOD hath elected and ordained, to eternall Life, through Christ.

Q. 29 What is meant by the enmity that God hath put betweene the seed of the woman, and
the seed of the Serpent?
A. It is to be taken two ways; first, as it is a work of the Divell in the wicked: Secondly, as it is the grace of God in the faithfull.
Q. 30. What is it as it is a worke of the Divel in the wicked?
A. It is a deadly and an unreconcileable hatred, that the wicked beare towards the godly, as Cain did to Abel, 1 Io. 3.12.
Q. 31. What is it, as it is the grace of God in the godly?

A. It is the grace
whereby they (out of their hatred to sinne and zeale of Gods glory) have such an heart-rising against all ungodly persons, as causeth them to shun all familiarity and needlesse company-keeping with them.
Q. 33. What is meant by the head of the Serpent, and by breaking the head of the Serpent?

A. By the head of the Serpent, is meant the power that the Divell had over all mankind; by the breaking of the head of the Serpent, is meant the destroying of that power
so as he shall never be able to bring any of the true children of God to eternall destruction.
Q. 34. How hath Christ destroyed that power?
A. By his active and passive obedience, whereby hee hath pacified the wrath, and satisfied the justice of God.
Q. 35. How doth Christ now (he being in Heaven) destroy the power of the Divell?

A. By the preaching of the Gospel, and working of his holy Spirit, he doth now open mens
eyes, and turnes them from darknesse to light, and from the power of Sathan unto God, Acts 26.18. Also, by the vertue of his death and resurrection, with the working of his holy Spirit by his Word; he doth mortifie sinne in the children of God, and doth raise them up to newnesse of life, Rom. 3.4, 5.
Q. 36. Is nothing else meant by the breaking of the Serpents head?

A. Yes, thereby is meant, that Christ hath, and now doth, and will, untill the day of judgement,
defend and protect the faithfull, and also subdue, confound, and destroy all his and their enemies, and then when all enemies are subdued, he will deliver up his kingdome into the hands of God the Father that gave it him, 1 Cor. 15.24, 25, 26.
Q. 37. It is written that of Christ his Kingdome there shall be no end, Luke 1.33. Why then doe you say, that hee will deliver it up into the hands of God the Father?

A. The Kingdome of
Christ is to be considered of two wayes, either as it is temporall, or as it is naturall and eternall.
Q. 38. What is his temporall kingdome, that shall be delivered up into the hands of God the Father?

A. His temporal kingdome is, that whereby he doth by his divine power governe and protect his people in the midst of their enemies, Psal. 2.6, 9.110.2. and whereby he doth over-rule, curbe, subdue, confound and destroy their enemies, in his good time.
Q. 9. What is his natural and eternall Kingdome?
A. His naturall and eternall Kingdome, is that wherby he hath supreme eminencie over men and Angels, as he is God equall with his Father.
Q. 40. Now come to the last words, which are these, Thou shalt bruise his heele: shew the meaning of them?

A. The meaning is, that when Sathan doth shew his malice in persecuting Christ, or any of his, the worst that hee can do, is, but as a prick in the heele, which is farre
enough from the heart.
Q. 41. What did God to Evah for harkning to the Serpent?

A. God did greatly increase her sorrowes, and conceptions, and told her, that in sorrow shee should bring forth children, and that her desire should be subject to her husband, and that hee should rule over her.
Q. 42. What did God to Adam for hearkning to the voyce of his wife?

A. For Adams sake, God cursed the earth, saying, cursed is the earth for thy sake, in sorrow
shalt thou eate thereof, all the dayes of thy life: thornes also and thistles shall it bring forth unto thee; and thou shalt eat the hearb of the field: In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eate thy bread, till thou returne to the earth.
Q. 42. Wherein did God curse the earth?
A. In making it barren, Psal. 107.34.
Q. 44. Why did God make the earth barren?

A. That thereby sorrow might come to Adam and to all his posteritie,
all the dayes of their life.
Q. 45. Why all the dayes of their life?
A. Because no part of their life is free from sin.
Q. 46. Doe all feel the sorrowes of this life alike?

A. No, the ungodly, for the most part, do feel them least, Psal. 73.3, 4, 5. Io. 21.9.13. and children, that have good parents, and servants that have good masters, and women that have good husbands to provide for them.

Q 47. Why did God
curse the earth and not Adam?
A. Because hee was one of them with whom God, had according to his eternall purpose made an everlasting Covenant of grace.
Q. 48. What is the Covenant of Grace?
A. That you may the better understand what the Covenant of grace is, it is needfull that I first speak of some things that God did before he made the world?
Q. 49. What did God before hee made the world?

A. As a man that purposeth to build an house, and hath resolved upon the roomes, what, and how many to make, doth in conceit see every room how fitly it will serve his turne: Even so Almighty God, with whom all things to come are alwayes, as present, did know, and see every creature in Heaven and Earth.
Q. 50. Did God then see, that some of the Angels would grow proud of their glory?

A. Yes, and that therby they would make a
way for his wrath and justice to appeare, in depriving them of their glory, and to cast them out of Heaven to Hell.
Q. 51. Did God see, what would become of them after they were cast out of Heaven to hell?

A. Yes, God saw that they would come to bee Devils, and that one of them (envying the happinesse of Adam and Evah, would tempt her to eat of the forbidden fruit, and that she would tempt and draw her husband to cat, and so break the Covenant and make way for
his wrath and Justice to appeare, depriving them also of the glorious state wherein they lived.
A. 52. Did God see what would become of them after they were deprived of that estate?
A. Yes, God saw that they would come to bee most miserable, corrupt, and sinfull wretches.
Q 53. Did God see that they would bring forth children, like themselves, corrupt and sinfull?

A. Yes, and that sin as a leprosie, would goe
over and infect all mankinde from one generation to another, and so make way for his wrath and justice, to appeare in condemning all.
Q. 54. How doth it appeare that corruption and sinfulnesse, is derived from parents to their children?

A. It appeareth by that which is written of Adam, that he did beget a child in his owne likenesse, that is, corrupt and sinfull, like himselfe, Gen. 5.3. and by the confession of the Prophet David, where hee saith, I was
borne in iniquitie and conceived in sinne, Psal. 51.5.
Q 55. What did God, when hee saw that a way was made for his justice to appeare in condemning all?

A. God being a God of mercy, as well as a God of justice, did resolve and purpose to save some, and (out of his free love) to bestow his onely sonne Jesus Christ upon them in marriage, Isai 9.6. Mat. 22.2.
Q 56. What did God after he was so purposed?

A. According to which his purpose and good
pleasure of his will, hee did elect so many as pleased him, Eph. 1.4, 5, 11. & did ordaine them, not unto wrath, but to obtaine salvation by meanes of our Lord Jesus Christ, 1 Thess. 5.9. and to come to a new agreement, and to make an everlasting Covenant of grace with them, Psal. 89.31, 32, 33, 34.
Q 57. By whose means was the new agreement obtained?
A. By meanes of Jesus Christ, 1 Tim. 2.1. Heb. 12.24.

Q. 57. Vpon what condition
was it granted?

A. It was granted upon condition that hee should discharge all their debt of sinne, by suffering for them, 1 Tim. 2.5, 6. and performing for them such an absolute obedience, Isai 53.6, 8. to the Law, as might justifie them, 2 Cor. 5.21. Rom 5.18, 19. Ier. 23.6.
Q. 59. After what manner was the Covenant made?
A. After the same manner that Covenants are made betweene man and man; as,

In Covenants between
man and man, matters are first agreed upon by both parties, then Articles of agreement are written, sealed, and delivered: so, in the Covenant of grace matters were first agreed upon by both parties, the holy Trinitie on the one partie, and all those whom God did purpose to save on the other part.
Q. 60. How could they be present to give their consent, cōsidering, that not one of them was then created.

A. There was no need of their being present because
they had their husband, Jesus Christ to mediate for them.
Q 61. Rehearse the Articles, that are to bee performed on Gods part,

A. They are many, and may be reduced into few that do comprehend all the rest. as first, that God for his owne great names sake, and for his beloved Sonne sake will forgive, and forget al the sinnes of the Elect for ever, Ier. 31.74. Secondly that God will take away their stony hart and give them a new heart and a new spirit. Ezeke: 36.26.
Thirdly, that God will out his Law into their inward parts, & write it in their hearts, Ier. 31.33. Fourthly, that God will put his Spirit within them, and cause them to walke in his statutes, Ezek 36.27. Fifthly, that God wil be their God, to defend and protect them from all their enemies, and their Father to provide for them all things necessary, Ier. 11.4. 2 Cor. 6.18.
Q. 62. Rehearse the articles that are to bee performed by us and all other the Children of God?
A. They also, are many, and may be reduced into few that doe comprehend all the rest.
Q. 63. What is the first?
A. That wee shall hate and renounce the Deuill and all his workes.
Q. 64. What is the second?
A. That we shall indevour to serve God, in holinesse and in righteousnesse all the dayes of our life, Luk. 1.74, 75.
Q. 65. What is the third?

A. That when through infirmitie, we doe breake
any of Gods Commandements, that then wee must neither presume, nor despaire, but repent, and beleeve in the Lord Jesus Christ, Mar. 1.15.
Q. 66. By whom were the Articles written?
A. By Moses and the Prophets, in the Old Testament.
Q. 67. To whom was the Covenant of Grace first revealed?

A. To Adam and Evah, when God said to the Divell in the Serpent, I will put enmity, betweene thee and the woman, and between thy seed and her
seed, it shall breake thine head, and thou shalt bruise his heele.
Q. 68. What Seales had the Covenant of Grace, in the Old Testament?
A. Circumcision and the Passeover were the two ordinary Seales.
Q. 69. VVhat was Circumcision?
A. Circumcision was a paring away of the fore-skin of the flesh.
Q. 70. VVhat was signified by the fore-skin?

A. It signified sinne,
that hath, as a leprosie, gone over and infected all man-kinde, from one generation to another.
Q. 71. VVhat was fignified by the paring and casting away of the fore-skin?

A. The fore-skin signified sinne; the paring and casting of it away, did signifie that God, for Christ his sake, doth forgive and cast out of his memory all the sinnes of all true beleevers for ever according to his promise in his everlasting Covenant of Grace, whereof Circumcision was a seale,
Ier. 31.34. Also the paring and casting away of the fore-skin, did signifie the grace that God giveth unto his children, to circumcise the fore-skin of their hearts.
Q. 72. VVhat is meant by the fore-skin of the heart?
A. By the fore-skin of the heart is not meant the skin that is about the heart, but the sinfull lusts and affections of the heart, Deut. 10.16. Ier. 4.4.
Q. 73. What is meant by the circumcising of the fore-skin of the heart?
A. By circumcising the fore-skin of the heart is meant the grace that God giveth to his children, to subdue the sinfull lusts and affections of their hearts.
Q. 74. VVhat was the Passeover?
A. The Passeover was a feast in Jerusalem, once in a yeere, to the killing and eating of a Lambe, called the Passeover.
Q. 75. VVherefore was that feast kept?

A. It was kept for a memoriall of the goodnesse of God in passing over the houses of the Israelites,
when by his Angel he slew the first borne in every house of the Egyptians.
Q. 76. VVhy is our Saviour Christ called our Passeover, 2 Corin. 5.7.
Our Saviour Christ is called our Passeover, because of the type and figure that was of him, in the Pascall Lambe.
Q. 77. VVherein was the Pascall Lambe a type and figure of our Savior Christ?
A. It was a type and figure of our Saviour Christ in many things:
As first, the Lambe was a male without blemish: so was our Saviour Christ a perfect man without sinne, 1 Pet. 1.
Secondly, the Lambe was patient, meeke, and harmlesse: so was Christ Isai. 53.7.
Thirdly, the Lambe was taken out of the flocke, and set apart to be kill'd; so was Christ (by the determinat counsell of God) to dye for all that beleeve in him, Act. 2.23.
Fourthly, the Lambe was kill'd towards the evening sacrifice: so was Christ.

Fifthly, the Lambe was was rosted with fire: fire signifieth the wrath and curse of God, Deut. 4.24. Isa. 66.15. and sometimes extreame and grievous paine, Mar. 9.34. The Lambe was rosted with fire, to prefigure the wrath and curse of God, and the grievous paine and torment that Christ suffered, Gal. 3.13.
Sixthly, the Lambe was eaten with bitter hearbes, to prefigure the afflictions and persecutions that the true followers of Christ are subject unto in this life.

Seventhly, the Lambe
was eaten with unlevened bread; leven doth signifie hypocrisie, corrupt doctrine, maliciousnesse and wickednesse: the Lamb was eaten with unlevened bread, to signifie, that the true professors of Christ ought to take heed of hypocrisie, corrupt doctrine, maliciousnesse and wickednesse Mat. 16.22. 1 Cor. 4.12.
Eightly, strangers and uncircumcised persons, were not to eate of it, to signifie, that infidels prophane and ungodly persons, that live and dye in their sinnes and unbeleefe have no part in Christ.

Ninthly, the Lord commanded, that the Lambe should have none of his bones broken: the strength of every living creature is in his bones, so as if you take away, or break the bones, you take away the strength: the not breaking the bones of the Lambe, did signifie, that though Christ did take on him for our sakes, more than he was able to beare, as hee was man, which did cost him his life, yet his divine power whereby hee was able to save all them for whom he dyed, and whereby he was able to be revenged of
all his and their enemies, was nothing diminished, which his divine power, he did shew in his death, by conquering death, according to the prophecie, Death is swallowed up in victory, Isai. 25.18. 1 Cor. 15.54. and by conquering him, that had power over death, that is, the Devill.
Q. 78. How doth it appeare, that the death of Christ did conquer death and the Devill?

A. It appeareth by the triumph and shew, that Christ did openly make, when hee gave up the
Ghost upon the Crosse, Col 2.15.
Q. 79. VVherein did the shew of triumph appeare?
A. It appeared, in that the Graves did open, and many bodies of the Saints did rise, and came out of the Graves, as soone as Christ was risen, and appeared unto many.
Q. 80. VVhat use ought we to make of the triumph?

A. It serveth to stirre us up with joyfull and glad hearts, to love the Lord Jesus, and to insult over death, as Saint Paul
did, when he said, O death where is thy victory: the sting of death is sinne, the strength of sin is the Law, but thankes be unto God, who hath given us victory through Iesus Christ, 1 Cor. 15.55, 56, 57.
Q. 81. Now that you have shewed what seales the Covenant of grace had in the old Testament, it remaineth that you shew what seales it hath in the New Testament?
A. The seales of the New Testament, are Baptisme and the Lords Supper.
Q. 82. VVhat are wee principally to consider of, in Baptisme?

A. We are to consider first, that the Minister doth represent God, sealing the Covenant of Grace: Secondly, that God by sealing the Covenant, doth bind himselfe to performe all promises and grants therein contained, as a man by putting his hand and seal to a writing, doth binde himselfe to performe all promises and grants therin contained.

Q. 83. Where do you finde the hand and seale
of God, to be in Baptisme?

A. As by a mans hand to a writing, is meant, not his hand cut off, and fastend to the writing, but his name or marke: so in Baptisme, the name of God, wherein Baptisme is ministred, is the hand of God, the water is the seale; the dipping or sprinkling of the water, is the putting to of the seale.
Q. 84. VVhether ought one to be dipped in, or but sprinkled with water?

A. It is a thing indifferent,
whether one bee dipped in, or but sprinkled, as appeareth by the example of the Apostles, who used both.
Q. 85. Can you name any that were dipped?
A. Yes, the Eunuch was dipped by Philip, Act. 8.38, 39. so also were they that were baptized by Iohn in Iorden, Mat. 3.6. and our Saviour Christ Mat. 3.16.
Q. 86. Can you name any that were but sprinkled?

A. Yes, Cornelius was but sprinkled, by S. Peter in his owne house, Acts
10.47. and S. Paul by Ananias, in the house of Iudas of Damascus, Acts 9.11.18. and the keeper of the Prison by Saint Paul in the prison house, Acts 16.33.
Q. 87. VVhich do you take to be most convenient?

A. In cold Countries, where one may receive hurt by being dipped, sprinkling is rather to be used, but in hot Countries, dipping is most convenient, because dipping doth more fully represent our being in Christ.

Q. 88. How doth dipping
represent our being in Christ?

A. The water doth represent, not the blood onely, but also whole Christ, body and soule, the being of the body in the water, doth represent our being in Christ, in the true nature and substance of our bodies and of our soules.
Q. 89. How is the true nature and substance of our bodies and of our soules in Christ?

A. The true nature and substance of our bodies and souls, is in Christ, in that the body of Christ
was incarnate, and made flesh of our flesh, and his soule of the same spirituall substance that our soules are of.
Q. 90. VVhen the body is in the water, it is as a dead body, in the grave, within the earth: what doth that signifie?

A. It signifieth, that we (in our true nature and substance of body and soule) were in Christ, when hee was dead and buried, according as it is written, Wee are buried with Christ in Baptisme into his death, Romans 6.4.
Q. 91. VVhat benefit have we by our being in Christ, in our true nature and substance of our bodies and soules, when hee was dead and buried?

A. Wee are thereby made partners of the merit of his death and buriall, so as thereby the justice of God is satisfied, and his wrath is pacified: God of his goodnesse, accepting of his suffering for us, in the true nature and substance of our bodies and soules, as though we our selves had suffered
in our bodies and in our soules.
Q. 92. Have we any other benefit by the death and buriall of Christ, in our true nature and substance?

A. Yes, thereby we are made partakers of the vertue of his death and buriall, so as thereby together with the working of his holy Spirit, by his Word sinne is mortified, and kept under, from having dominion over us, and we are raised to newnesse of life, according as it is written, If wee bee grafted with him to the similitude
of his death, even so shall we be to the similitude of his resurrection, knowing this, that the old man is crucified with him, that the body of sinne might be destroyed, that henceforth wee should not serve sinne, Rom. 6.4, 5, 6.
Q. 93. Christ is now in Heaven, in our true nature and substance, of body and soule, what benefit have we thereby?

A. Thereby, wee in Christ) are in Heaven already, in full possession of it, and have possession kept for us, by Christ, till our appointed time bee
come, in the mean while Christ sitteth on the right hand of God, making intercession for us.

Q. 95. What if a weak Christian finde such corruption to be in his nature, and such rebellion to be in his heart, and the sinne that dwelleth in him, to be so strong, as makes him to feare, that hee is not a partaker of these benefits?

A. Let him not despaire, but assure himselfe that the feeling of his imperfections and of the rebellion of his heart, and
of the strength of sin that dwelleth in him, is a sure signe and token, that hee is not dead in trespasses and in sin, and that the life of grace is in him, and that God hath a loving care of him, and therfore doth give to him a sight and feeling of themiserable estate he is in by natur that thereby he may prepare and fit him, and also stirre him up, to lay hold on the Covenant of grace, which was sealed unto him, when he was baptised.

For the more strengthning of his faith let him call to mind, that as verily,
as when hee was baptised, the Minister did then take his name, and did baptise him by his name: so verily God the Father did then take and acknowledge him by name, to be his child, and did then seale his everlasting Covenant of grace to him by name, and for his further comfort, let him assure himselfe, that as the Minister did then know him by name, and did write or cause his name to be written in the Church-Book among the Saints Militant, here on earth: so verily God doth now
know him by his name, and hath his name written among the Saints triumphant in heaven. Luk 10.20. Phil. 4.3. Revel. 21.27.
Q. 95. When a weake Christian doth feele his sinnes, to lye upon his heart and conscience, as a burthen too heavy for him to beare; what must he doe to finde some ease?

A. He must then also thinke upon his baptisme, and assure himselfe, that as verily as he was baptized in the name of the Sonne; so verily, Jesus Christ the Sonne of God
hath suffered for his sins, and washed them all away in his precious bloud 1 Io. 1.7. And that as verily, as he was baptized in the name of the Holy Ghost; so verily, God in his good time will give his holy Spirit unto him, to sanctifie, guide, comfort, and preserve him to eternall life through Jesus Christ, according to his promise in his everlasting Covenant of Grace, which was sealed unto him when he was baptized.

Qu. 97. How may a weake Christian know
and bee assured that hee hath the Spirit of God?

A. Hee may easily know the Spirit of God, by the crying that it maketh within him, according as it is written, Gal. 4.6. Because ye are sonnes, God hath sent forth the Spirit of his Son into your hearts, which cryeth Abba, Father.
Qu. 98. Doth the Spirit of God cry?
A. No, the meaning is, that it makes them that have it to cry.

Q. 99. They that cry are much offended, and
grieved: what is that that doth so offend and grieve weake Christians?

A. The sight and feeling of the corruption of their nature and of the strength of sinne, that dwelleth, in them, and of their own weaknesse and readinesse to yeeld to the corruption of their nature, and to the sinne that dwelleth in them.
Q. 100. Why doth God give them such a sight and feeling of the cursed and damnable estate that they are in by nature?
A. God doth it, to humble them, and to make them fit for true and sound comfort, and joy in the Holy Ghost.
Q. 101. How are they brought to have true and sound comfort?

A. By the sight that the Spirit of Christ giveth them of the eternall love and goodnesse of God, in electing them for his children, and in ordaining them to eternall life, through Jesus Christ, and in making an everlasting Covenant of Grace with them.

Qu. 102. How are
they brought to have that sight?
A. By the Grace that the Spirit of God worketh in them to heare his holy Word, Acts 26.18.
Q. 103. How is faith wrought in them?
A. By hearing the Word of God, Rom. 10.17.
Q. 104. How is a true lively faith known from a dead faith?
A. By purifying the heart, that is, by working such a change in the heart, as bringeth forth a reformed life, Acts 15.9.
Q. 105. You said, that the Spirit of God, is known by the crying that it maketh in them, that have it: what doth it cry?
A. The Spirit of God it selfe doth not cry, but makes them to cry that have it.
Q. 106. And what doe they cry?
A. They cry Abba, Father.
Q. 107. What is meant by crying Abba, Father?

A. The meaning is, that as soone as a childe of God hath Faith
though but in a weake measure, to beleeve that God is his father, he doth then cry and call upon God his Heavenly Father for mercy and forgivenesse, and for grace to amend what hath beene amisse in him.
Whosoever doth finde this grace of God in himselfe, may assure himselfe that he is a child of God, and that his faith is a true faith, though weake.

Q. 108. Now that you have shewed what use every christian ought to make, of being baptized in the Name of the
Father, Sonne and Holy Ghost, it remaineth that you shew, what use every Christian ought to make of giving his name to the Minister before hee did baptize him,

A. The giving of our names to the Minister, serveth first to put every Christian in minde, that as verily as hee did give his name to the Minister, so verily did he then give his name unto God, whō the Minister did then represent: Secondly, it serveth to put him in minde, that hee did receive Baptisme, not only
as a seale of the Covenant of Grace, but also as a seale or marke wherewith hee was sealed and marked for one of Gods Covenant servants, and that he did receive it as an earnest penny to bind him to serve God, in holinesse and in righteousnesse all the dayes of his life: and that therefore, as he hopeth to enter into his Masters joy, (the joyes of heaven) his greatest care and endevour ought to bee to serve God.

Q. 109. What if his conscience doth tell him,
that he hath broken Covenant with God?
A. He must not therefore despaire, but repent and beleeve in the Lord Jesus, and come as soone as he can to the Table of the Lord to renue his Covenant.

div.head: Of the Lords Supper.
div.p: Q. 110. What are the principall things that we are to consider of in the Lords Supper?
A. Wee are first to consider that it is an holy Ordinance of the Lord Jesus, and therefore not to be neglected, nor lightly regarded.

Q. 111. Is it to be regarded now as much as it was then, when it was
first instituted and administred by the Lord Iesus himselfe?
A. Yes verily, because it is now as it was then, a seale of the Covenant of Grace, and the Lord Jesus is present now as well as then.
Q. 112. How is the Lord Iesus present?
A. He is present with the receivers by his Spirit, according to his promise, Where two or three are gathered together in my name, there am I in the middest of them.

He is also present with the elements of bread and
wine, by his divine power blessing them, so as they are effectuall seales, to ratifie the Covenant of Grace, and to convey Christ and all his merits to every faithfull receiver.
Q. 113. Why doth the Pope and his followers say, that Christ is really present, and that the bread is the very flesh, and the wine is the very blood of Christ?

A. Because they are given over into strong delusion to beleeve lyes, 2 Thess. 2.8, 9, 10, 11. They may as well say,
that the Cup is the New Testament, because it is written, that our Savior tooke the Cup and said, This Cup is the new Testament, 1 Corin. 11.25. Luk. 22.20.
Q. 114. When was the Lords Supper instituted?

A. It was instituted as soone as Christ was risen from eating the Pascall Lambe, and had washt his Disciples feet, and was set down againe with his Disciples, to a little banquet, that the Jewes did use to make then, as an entrance into the feast of
unlevend bread, which did then begin, and continued seven dayes.
Q 115. What had they to that banquet?
A. They had a Cake of unlevened bread, and a cup of wine, and a Sallet of bitter hearbs and soure sawce.
Q. 116. Why was the Cake unlevened?
A. To put them in minde of the sudden departure of their Fathers out of Egypt, so as they had no time to leven their dough.

Q. 117. What was signified by the bitter
hearbes and soure sawce?
A. The bitter hearbes and soure sawce was to put them in minde of the bondage and bitter afflictions of their Fathers in Egypt.
Q. 118. Was any thing signified by the bondage of their Fathers in Egypt?
A. Yes, thereby was signified the spirituall bondage of mankind under sinne, Satan, and death eternall.
Q. 119. Shew the manner of that banquet?

A. It was thus, the Master of the Family
tooke the Cake of bread, & gave thankes, and then broke it in two parts, and set one part by it selfe, covering it with a napkin, and divided the other among them, that sat at Table with him, which they did eate with the Sallet, dipping their morsels in the platter.
Q 120. What did they after the Sallet was eaten?

A. As soone as the Sallet was eaten, the Master of the Family tooke the other halfe of the Cake, and broke to every one a peece, saying, This
is the bread of affliction, that our fore-fathers did eate in Egypt, &c.
Q, 121. What did they after that bread was eaten?

A. The Master of the Family tooke the Cup, called the Cup of blessing and gave thankes, and gave it to him that sate next unto him, and he to the next, and so from one to another, till every one had sipt a little.
Q 122. Why was the Cup called the Cup of blessing?

A. It was called the Cup of blessing, because
it was never used, but when they did assemble themselves together, publikely to blesse and praise God for some great deliverance or blessing bestowed upon them.
Q. 123. VVhy was the bread called the bread of affliction?

A. It was called the bread of affliction, to put them in minde, that they were then and there assembled, to praise God for his mercy, in delivering their Fathers out of Egypt, and also for his mercy in delivering them and their Fathers, from
the bondage of sinne and Sathan, and from death eternall, by the promised Messiah Jesus Christ, whom the Pascall Lamb and the unlevened bread did then represent, unto them, as the bread and wine in the Lords Supper do now unto us.
Q. 124. What did they after that every one had drunke of the Cup?
A. As soone as every one had drunke, they did praise God with singing of Psalmes, and then departed every man to his own lodging.

Q. 125. VVhere doth
it appeare, that our Saviour Christ and his Disciples had such a banquet?

A. In the tenth chapter of the Gospel written by Saint Iohn, we reade, that when supper was ended, that is, when the Pascall Lamb was eaten, our Saviour Christ did rise and wash his Disciples feet, and that after he had washed their feet, he sate downe with his Disciples againe, and did eat and drinke, and dip their morsels in the platter.

Q. 126. VVas Iudas
then among the Disciples?
A. Yes, and was discovered to be a Traytor.
Q. 127. Who did discover him?

A. Our Saviour Christ himselfe, when he tould his Disciples that one of them would betray him, and that it was hee, to whom hee gave a sop, which hee tooke, and gave to Iudas, whereupon Satan entred into him, and he went out immediately.
Q. 128. What did Christ after that Iudas was gone?
A. Christ did then institute this Sacrament, which wee call the Lords Supper.
Q. 129. After what manner?

A. After the same manner, that the Master of the Family did observe in the banquet above mentioned, as first the Master of the family, took bread, gave thanks, and then broke it, and gave it to them that sate at Table with him: so Christ tooke bread, gave thankes, and then broke it and gave it to the Disciples.
Q. 130 To whom, and for what did Christ give thankes?
A. He gave thankes to God the Father, for his goodnesse in ordaining all that doe truly beseeve in him to eternall life, and in making our everlasting Covenant of Grace with them.
Q. 131 It is written, that Christ tooke bread and blessed it, how did he blesse it?

A. Christ blessed the bread, as God the Father blessed the seventh day; God blessed the seventh day by ordaining the
keeping of it holy, to be a meanes to bring a blessing on all them that doe remember it, to keep it holy: even so our Saviour Christ blessed the bread, by ordaining it to bee a meanes, to bring his blessing on all them that doe receive it, according as he did then institute and appoint.

Also, by his blessing the bread, wee are to understand, that Christ did pray, and by prayer did obtaine of God, that his blessing shall come on all them that doe receive it according as he did then institute and appoint.

The example of our Saviour Christ in giving thankes, and in blessing the bread, serveth to teach us, when we are at the Lords Table, to acknowledge the goodnes of God in electing us for his children, and in ordaining us to eternall life through Jesus Christ, and in making an everlasting Covenant of Grace with us, and to give him heartie thankes, and to pray for his blessing upon our receiving.

Q. 132. Now goe on as you began, to shew after what manner this holy
Sacrament was instituted and administred by our Saviour Christ?

A. As the Master of a Family, when he gave the bread, did say, This is the bread of affliction that our fathers did cate in Egipt: so our Saviour Christ, when he gave the bread, said, This is my body which is broken for you, doe this in remembrance of me.

As the master of the Family tooke the Cup, and gave thankes, and then gave it to them that sat at Table with him: so Christ tooke the Cup,
gave thankes, and then gave it to his Disciples, saying, drinke you all of this, for this is my blood of the New Testament.
Lastly, as the master of the Family, and they that were with him did sing Psalmes, so did our Saviour Christ and his Disciples sing a Psalme.
Q. 133. Now shew what is signified by every thing in the Lords Supper?

A. The bread doth signifie the body of Christ: the breaking of the bread doth signifie the breaking and tearing of the
Flesh of Christ with the nayles, when they were driven thorow his hands and feet, and with the speare, when it was thrust into his side: The wine doth signifie the Blood of Christ: the giving of the bread and wine, doth signifie, that God doth then seale the Covenant of Grace, and doth offer and freely give Christ, and all his merits to every faithfull creature.
Qu. 134. What doth the receiving of the bread and wine signifie?

A. The receiving of the bread and wine doth
signifie the grace of God in the faithfull, whereby they doe lay hold (by faith) on the Covenant of grace, and doe apply all the promises and grants therein contained, unto themselves, and that they doe receive and take Christ only for their Saviour, and doe renounce all their owne merits.
Qu. 135. What doth the eating of the bread, and drinking of the wine signifie?

A. Thereby is signified the grace of God in the faithfull, whereby
their soules doe feede on Christ.
Qu. 136. How doe their soules feede on Christ?
A. By beleeving that the body of Christ was crucified, and that his blood was shed for them, and that thereby the wrath of God is pacified, and his justice satisfied.
Q. 137. What is signified by the comfort, strength and nourishment that the body doth receive from the bread and wine?

A. Thereby is signified,
that as the life of man is preserved, comfortably, by the vertue that God hath given to the bread, to strengthen the heart, and to wine, to make it glad, Psal. 104.10. so Christ by his divine power and grace, doth nourish, comfort and preserve the faithfull to eternall life.
Qu. 138. How ought I to spend the time while the Minister is in delivering the bread and wine?

A. In regard, that God doth then seale the Covenant of Grace, doe
thou therefore passe thy time in meditating upon the Covenant, and upon the promises and grants therein contained, and apply them to thy selfe, as,
First, that God for Christ his sake will forgive and forget all thy sinnes for ever, if thou dost truly repent thee of thy sinnes, and beleeve in the Lord Jesus.

Secondly, if the hardnesse of thy heart and dulnesse of thy spirit doth grieve thee, assure thy selfe, that God (in his good time) will take from thee thy stony
heart, and will give thee a new heart, and a new spirit.

Thirdly, if want of grace, to remember the word of God, doth grieve thee, assure thy selfe that God will put it into thine inward part, and write it in thine heart, so much as shall be sufficient to thy salvation.

Fourthly, if want of grace, to have a comfortable feeling of Gods holy Spirit, to beare witnesse with thy spirit, that thou art a childe of God, doth grieve thee, assure thy selfe, that God (in his good time) will give
thee his holy Spirit, to assure thee, that he is thy God, to defend and protect thee from all enemies, and thy Father, to provide for thee all things necessary.

For the performance of these promises, God must be sought unto by hearty prayer, Ezech. 36.37. therefore pray not onely when thou art at the Lords Table, but continually, and pray in faith without doubting, because God, who hath made these promises, is a God of truth: Heaven and earth shall passe away, but Gods Word
shall not passe away unfulfilled.

Also, in regard our Saviour Christ saith, Do this in remembrance of me; therefore faile not to thinke upon Christ, and upon the grievous paine that he endured for thee in his body, when he was scourged, and when the nayles were driven thorow his hands and feet, and when he hung bleeding on the Crosse, with the waight of his whole body on his hands, which did teare the flesh, and inlarge the holes that the nayles had made in his hands.

Thinke also upon the torments that Christ suffered in his soule for thee, when he complained that his soule was heavie, even unto the death, and when in the agony of his soule he did sweat water & blood, and when on the Crosse, hee cryed out, saying, O God my God, why hast thou forsaken me.

Let the love of Christ in suffering such grievous pains and torments, move thee to love him againe, and to be truely zealous of his glory, and carefull to serve and please him, in holinesse
and righteousnesse all the dayes of thy life.

Lastly, call to minde that when thou wast baptized, thou didst receive baptisme, not only as a seale of the Covenant of grace, but also as a seale and marke wherewith thou wast sealed and marked for one of Gods Covenant-servants and that thou didst receive baptisme as an earnest penny, to bind thee unto God, to serve him in holinesse and righteousnesse.

If thy conscience doth tell thee, that thou hast broke Covenant with
God, doe not therefore despaire, but repent and beleeve in the Lord Jesus, and (before thou goest from the Lords Table) renue thy Covenant by purposing and resolving with thy selfe, and also by vowing and promising unto God, that by his grace thou wilt have a care to serve him.

div.head: Godly Instructions, shewing, how to put every Petition of the Lords Prayer in practice, and how to spend every day in holy meditations, and how to make some spiritull use of the things that we shall see or heare.
div.p:
AS soone as thou art awake in the morning thinke upon the goodnesse of God, in keeping thee, from all perils and dangers
of the night, and in bestowing quiet rest and sleepe upon thee, and give him hearty thankes, and in token of love and thankfulnesse, resolve with thy selfe, by the grace of God, to have a care to serve and please him when thou art up and ready, and love the Lord Jesus, because it is for his sake that God is good unto thee.

2. If thou hast had a bad nights rest, acknowledge the goodnesse of God, in that it was not so bad as thou deservest, and with a penitent heart, confesse thy sinnes unto
God, because it is written, that man suffereth for sinne, Lam. 3.39.

div.head: A Prayer for the morning.
div.p:
O Heavenly Father, forgive me my sins for Christ Jesus his sake, and give me grace to amend my life, keepe mee this day, that no evill come unto mee: keepe me from sinne especially, and from Satan and all his instruments: keepe mee also in health and strength of body and minde: blesse unto me all
thy good creatures that I shall use this day, and give mee grace to use them temperately, and thankfully: blesse also all crosses and troubles unto me, that they may turne to thy glory and my good. Lord guide mee with thy holy Spirit, instruct mee with thy holy Word, and prosper mee in every good thing that I shall take in hand to thy glory through Jesus Christ. Amen.

3. God onely is the Creator, preserver, Governour, and disposer of all things in heaven and
earth; therefore be contented with thine estate, how meane soever it be, and trust to Gods providence, and have God alwayes in thy minde, and pray for grace, to set forth the praise and glory of his holy and great Name, according to the meaning of the first Petition of the Lords Prayer.

4. Follow not the sway of thy owne corrupt lusts, let not them over-rule thee, but pray to God to rule and governe thee, by his Word and holy Spirit, according to the meaning of the second
Petition.

5. Make conscience of the least sinne, and take heed of following thine owne will, in any thing, and pray continually for grace to doe Gods holy will, in all things, according to the meaning of the the third Petition.

6. Abhorre idlenesse and take paines for thy living honestly, in the feare of God: be content with thine estate, how meane so ever it be, trust to Gods providence, and pray continually for such things as thou standest in need of, according to the meaning of the fourth Petition.

7. Confesse thy sinnes unto God every day, and pray to God to forgive thee thy sinnes, for Christ his sake; pray also for grace to bee loving and tender-hearted, alwayes ready to forgive such as shall offend thee, even as thou lookest to bee forgiven at Gods hands, according to the meaning of the fifth Petition.
8. Pray to God every day for grace to amend thy life, and to deliver thee from evill, that is, from the power and poyson of sin, Satan, and the World, according to the meaning of the 6. Petitiō.

9. When thou art about to rise, thinke upon our Resurrection in the day of judgement: They that have done good unto the Resurrection of life, and they that have done evill, to the resurrection of condemnation, Joh. 5, 28, 29.
10. When thou art about to put on thy clothes, think upon God and his goodnesse, in providing them for thee, and give him heartie thankes.

11. And (to keep thee from being proud of thy clothes) thinke upon the sinfulnesse of thy soule, and vilenesse of thy body,
that is under them.

If thy clothes be poore and ragged, thanke God for them, because they are more then God doth owe thee, and better then thou deservest, and bee more ashamed of thy sins then of thy clothes, and more carefull, to forsake thy sinnes, then to get better clothes.
12. When thou art up and ready, pray unto God for his grace and protection, because many a one goeth out well in the morning, and hath dyed before night.

13. When thou art about to eate, or drinke,
thinke upon God and his goodnesse, in providing food for thee, and desire him, for Christ his sake, to blesse it unto thee, and take heed, that the sinne of gluttony, surfeting, or drunkennesse, doe not steale upon thee, in the time of the eating and drinking.
14. When thou art going about thy businesse, pray unto God, to blesse and prosper thee, because without Gods blessing thy labour is in vaine, Psal. 127.

Have God alwayes in thy mind, as an eye-witnesse to every thing thou
dost, and that he will one day judge thee according to thy doings.

15. When God doth blesse and prosper thee, so as thou dost grow rich, give God thankes and take heed thou settest not thy heart upon thy riches, and that thou bee not high-minded, nor hard-hearted towards the poore, but shew thy selfe to be a childe of God, in being mercifull, as thy heavenly Father is mercifull.

16. If thou beest an hired servant or a poore labourer, strive to be as thankfull unto God for

thy wages, as the rich are for their riches.

17. Be faithfull to them whom thou dost serve or worke for, and suffer nothing to bee lost, through thy negligence, as many servants doe their broken bread and meat, which is not onely a losse to their master, but also an offence to the Lord Jesus, who would have all broken meate to be gathered up and saved, that nothing bee lost, Iohn 6.12.

18. When thou hast bin abroad and art come home safe, forget not to acknowledge and confesse
unto God, his goodnesse in keeping thee safe, & in providing an home for thee, and above all things, for his goodnesse in providing an everlasting home for thee in heaven, where thou shalt rest for ever, in fulnesse of joyes, through Jesus Christ, if thou doft repent and beleeve in him.

19. When at home or abroad, thou seest variety of Gods creatures, provided for the use of man, doe thou then acknowledge and confesse unto God, his bounty and goodnesse, and love the Lord Jesus with all thine
heart, because it is for his sake that God is so good unto us.

20. When thou seest the fowles of the ayre, that have no body to make provision for them in Summer against winter, then thinke upon Gods speciall providence and goodnesse in feeding them in deepe of winter, so as for the most part, they are then fatter then in Summer, and that therefore no childe of God ought to despaire, or the any unlawfull means, will God so provide for the fowles of the ayre, and neglect his owne children?
no, no, he cannot doe it.

21. When thou seest the beauty, or smellest the sweet savour of some flowers, then thinke upon the goodnesse of God in creating them, for our delight and comfort, and reason thus with thy self: if these creatures bee so beautifull and comfortable, much more is God, that made them: happy therefore are they that are in heaven, beholding his glory.

22. When thou seest the Flowers, how they wither and perish, then thinke upon thy mortalitie,
and therewith bee humbled, and admonished, to prepare and make thy selfe ready for death.

23. When thou seest the hearbes how they grow and spring againe, then thinke upon our Resurrection in the day of judgement, they that have done good, unto the Resurrection of life, and they that have done evill, unto the Resurrection of condemnation, Iohn 5.28, 29. and pray for grace so to live, as thou mayest rise to life eternall, through Jesus Christ.

24. When thou seest or dost smell the noysome savour of some weeds then thinke upon sinne, how offensive it is to A mighty God, and let the care that some men have to keepe weeds under, put thee in minde how carefull thou shouldest be, to keep sinne under, and not suffer it to raigne and have dominion over thee.

25. When thou seest it raine, then think upon the providence or God, in laying up water in stores in the clouds to moisten the earth at his pleasure, and praise him. Thinke
then also upon the Word of God, and pray that God would blesse his holy word to thee, as hee doth the raine unto the earth, Isai. 10.11. Heb. 6.7.

26. When too much raine doth spoile the fruit of the earth, or want of raine doth make it barren, then think upon thy sinnes, and the sinnes of the land, because they are the cause thereof, Levit. 26.19. Deut. 28.24. Amos 4.7. and repent thee of thy sinnes, and pray for the people, that they also may repent.

27. When thou seest it snow, then think upon the blood of Christ, how it washeth thee from thy sinnes, and makes thee whiter then the snow, if by true faith and repentance, thou turne to him, otherwise not, Psalme 51.7.
28. When thou hearest it thunder, then think upon the power of God, wherewith he is able to shake both heaven and earth, and feare not the thunder, but God, whose voyce it is, Psal. 29.4.

29. When thou seest it lighten, then thinke upon the power of God,
whereby hee is able to burne and consume the whole world, and feare not the lightning, but God, whose arrow it is, and killeth none but whom hee will, Psalme 144.6.

Aso, when thou seest it lighten, thinke upon the comming of our Saviour Christ unto judgement, because it is written that, As the lightning commeth from the East, and shineth unto the West, so shall the comming of the Sonne of man be, Matth. 24.27.

The comming of our Saviour Christ to judgement,
is compared to lightning, to shew, that as lightning commeth on the sudden, so shall the comming of our Saviour be, and that as lightning when it shineth into a darke roome, doth make things hid in darkenesse to be seene: so our Saviour Christ, at his comming, will bring to judgment, things that are hid, and make the counsels of the heart manifest, 1 Cor. 4.5.

30. When thou seest the Sunne, thinke upon thy Saviour Christ Jesus, whom the Sunne doth fitly resemble, in that the 〈…〉
with his beames doth reach and shine throughout the whole the whole world; so, Christ by his spirit, grace, and power is, and ever will be present with the children of God, in all places of the world. Also, as the Sun doth give light and comfort to al living creatures, and therefore all living creatures except the hatefull Batts and Owles, doe love and rejoyce in the Sunne, and doe draw neer unto it: so, our Saviour Christ doth enlighten, preserve, and comfort all Gods children, and therefore all
the true children of God doe love and rejoce in him.

31. When thou feest the Sunne, how it shineth on the good and on the bad, then think upon God thy heavenly Father, and examine thy selfe, whether thou bee like to him, in being willing and ready to doe good unto all, not onely to thy friends, but also to thine enemies, according to the words of our Saviour Christ, Matth. 5.44. Love your enemies, blesse them that curse you, doe good to them that hate you, that you may be the children
of your Father which is in heaven: for hee maketh his Sunne to shine on the evill and on the good.
32. Also when thou seest the Sun how it never stands still, be thereby put in minde of thy duty, never to be idle, nor wearie of well-doing.
The Sunne is a hundred and sixe times greater then the earth: therefore with an holy reverence admire the great wisdome and power of God, in creating it of nothing.

33. When thou seest the Starres, and considerest,
how glorious and beautifull they are, then thinke upon the glory of God, and reason thus, If these creatures be so glorious and beautifull, much more is God that created them, happy therefore are they, that are in heaven, beholding his glory.

Thinke also, upon the glory of the Saints in heaven, of whom it is written, that they doe shine as Starres for ever and for ever, Dan. 12.13. and love the Lord Jesus, because it is written: That he will change these our vile bodies, and make them like to his glorious
body, Philippians 3.21.

34. The glorified body of Christ, now in heaven, doth excell the brightest starre in glory: these our vile bodies shall be made like unto his glorious body: therefore these our vile bodies, shall excell the brightest starre in glory. Great cause therefore have wee to love the Lord Jesus, and to be zealous of his glory.

35. When thou art about to goe to bed, goe to thy prayer, and desire God to forgive thee thy sinnes, and give thee grace to amend thy life, and to receive thee into
his protection, and to bestow upon thee quiet rest and sleepe.

div.head: A Prayer for the Evening.
div.p:
O Most gracious God and loving Father, I doe from my heart acknowledge thy great goodnesse towards mee, in this day past, I doe also acknowledge my selfe to bee unworthy of the least of thy mercies, by reason of my sinnes, forgive mee my sinne for
Christ his sake, and give me grace to amend whatsoever thou seest to be amisse in mee, and for Christ his sake keepe me this night that no evill come unto me, and bestow upon mee quiet rest and sleepe, to refresh my weake body, to make mee stronger, and more fit to serve thee, to thy glory through Christ Iesus, Amen.

36. If thy bed and bedding, and the roome be good give God thanks if thy roome be meane
and cold, thy bed hard, and thy clothes few, bee thankefull to God, because it is better than thou deservest, and more than GOD doth owe thee.

38. When thou art laid in bed to sleep, think upon death and upon thy going to thy grave. Because death is compared to a sleep, Matth. 9.24. and the grave to a bed, Isai. 55.2. And in regard thou art not sure to live till morning, it standeth thee upon, to thinke upon thy sinnes, and with a penitent heart, to confesse them unto God, and
