div.head: OF CHRISTS walking in the middest of the seven golden Candlesticks.
div.p: Q. 1. VVhere is Christ to be found?

A. Thou shalt bee sure to find Christ, every Lords day in the Church walking in the midst of the seven golden Candlesticks, holding the 7. starrs in his right hand, &
walking in the midst of the golden Candlesticks, Rev. 2.1. to see who are true worshippers of God, that he may blesse them, and who are not, that hee may give them their portion with the hipocrites in the lake that burneth with fire and brimstone.
Q. 2. What is meant by the seven Starres?

A. The seven starres were the preachers of the Gospell in the seven Churches of Asia: now (that they are not) we are to understand by the seven starres, all faithfull
preachers of the Gospell, throughout the whole world.
Q. 3. Why are they called Starres?
A. They are called starres because of the light that they doe give unto the world, by their doctrine and good life. Mat. 5.14.
Quest. 4. Why is Christ said to hold them in his right hand?

A. Christ is said to hold them in his right hand, because he doth by his holy Spirit keepe them from falling into errors, and doth protect
them by his Divine power from all enemies, so farre as his holy Majesty doth see it fit for his owne glory.
Q. 5. What is meant by the seven golden Candlesticks?

A. The seven golden Candlesticks, were the seven Churches of Asia: now (that they are not) we are to understand every true Christian Congregation throughout the whole world, where God is truely worshipped.
Q. 6. Why are they called Candlesticks?

A. They are called Candlesticks to shew, that as a Candlestick doth beare and hold the candle to give light to such as have eyes to see: even so every Christian congregation, doth bear and hold forth, and publish to the world, the light of the glorious Gospell of Christ Iesus, by preaching and maintaining it, and by professing the Christian faith. Also they may be compared to Candlestickes to shew, that as a Candlesticke of it selfe hath no light in it; the light that it hath is put
into it, even so is it with every true Christian congregation, the light that every branch & member thereof hath, is put into them by Christ Iesus, that dwelleth in them by his word & holy Spirit.
Q. 7. Why are they called golden Candlesticks

A. They are called golden Candlesticks, to shew that as gold is the most excellent of all mettals, so every true Christian congregation, where God is truely worshipped, is the most excellent of all societies,
and companies of men in the world.
Q 8. Wherein doe they excell all other societies and companies?

A. They doe excell all others in the graces of Gods holy Spirit, they are also compared to golden Candlesticks to shew that as men doe make more reckoning of true Christians, than of any other people, and as men doe make gold their chiefest treasure and have a care to keepe it
safe, so is every true worshipper of God unto Christ, his chiefe treasure, that he hath a care of, therefore goe not into the holy Congregation as the hypocrites doe to abuse the holy and great Name of Almighty God, by taking it in vaine, even then, when they seeme to joyne with the congregation, in the true worship and service of God.
Q. 9. Wherein doe they then abuse and take the name of God in vaine?

A. They doe abuse it,
and take it in vaine, in that they doe not minde what they doe, all that they doe is but an outward shew of drawing neere unto God with their lips, having their hearts farre from him.
Q. 10. How doth that appeare?
A. It appeareth plainly by their sleeping, and by their whispering, and talking, and looking on this body, and on that body, when the word of God is read or preached unto them.

It appeareth also in that they doe not lift
up their hearts unto God when they pray, as the Prophet David did, Psal. 25. nor so much as think upon his holy and glorious Majesty, to speake with reverence unto him.
Q. 11. Wherein doth their want of reverence appeare?

A. It appeareth plainly by their leaning lazily on their elbowes, and by their sitting unreverently in time of prayer notwithstanding that the minister, doth put them in mind of kneeling in the Liturgie, out of the 59. Psalme. O
come let us worship, and fall downe, and kneele before the Lord our Maker. None but God knoweth whither for this great sin of abusing and taking the name of God in vain in time of Gods publique worship and service. God hath shewed fearefull Iudgements, and tokens of his wrath upon Churches, as appeareth by multitudes of Letters Patents, granted for the gathering of the benevolence of well disposed Christians for the repairing of Churches rent and spoiled with lightning and thundring
since the beginning of Queene Elizabeths raign especially on the 21. of October last, 1638. the parish Church of Withcombe in Devon-shire, being a faire and large Church, newly trimmed, having a very faire steeple like a Tower with great and small pinacles, one of the famousest Towers in the West part of England; there fell (in time of divine Service) a strange and great darkenesse, so as the people could not see one another, and a fearefull Thunder, much like the noyse or report of many
great Canons, and a fearfull lightning and loathsome smell like brimstone, and a strange and fearefull blast, that struck in at the North-side of the Towre, and tearing through a strong stone wall, came into the Church through the highest window, and tooke the greatest part thereof with it, and with a mightie power strucke against the North side wall of the Church, and did shake and batter the wall very much, threatning as though it would cast it downe, and then went towards the
Pulpet, and in the way tooke with it the lime and sand from the wall, and grated the stones and defaced the wall being newly trimmed, and tore away the side deske of the Pulpet, and coloured the Pulpet with black and left it moist, as if it had beene newly wiped over with inke.
The lightning did fright the people and scalded them, so as most part of them fell downe, some on their knees, some on their faces, some one upon another, crying.

The Ministers wife
had her ruffe and linnen next her body burnt cleane off, and her body grievously schorched.
One Mistris Ditford sitting in the seat with her had her gowne, two wastcoates, and her linnen next her body burnt cleane off, and her body grievously scorched.
An other woman running out of the Church had her clothes set on fire, and her body scorched, and her flesh torne on her back.
A dog neere the chancell doore was whirld up three times, and fel down dead.
One Master Hill a gentleman, had his head smit against the wall, and died that night.

Sir Richard Reynolds Warrener, had his head cloven, his scull rent into three pieces, whereof two fell into the next seate, the other fell down in the seat where he sate; his braines fell intire and whole into the next seat behind him, his blood dasht against the wall: some of the skin of his head, flesh and haire, to the quantitie of an handfull was carried into the Chancell, and stuck fast, as with lime and sand
newly tempered, upon one of the posts between the Church and the Chancell, his body was left in the seat as though it had been alive, sitting asleepe, leaning upon his elbow, his elbow resting on the deske before him, with the fore-part of his head and face whole, as some say.
A man that sate next to him in the same seate was scolded and burnt all over on that side next the Warrenner.

In the second seat behind the Warrenner, an other man in a most grievous manner was
burnt and scalded all over his bodie, from his head downwards below his knees, so as he was all over like raw flesh, and his cloathes nothing hurt, nor his head and haire, and lived in great misery about a weeke.

Some seates in the body of the Church were torne up, and turned upside downe, and they that sate in them, had no harme, notwithstanding that they were throwne out of them into other seates three or foure seates higher: about the number of eight boyes setting about the
railes of the Communion Table were taken up and throwne on heapes within the railes and had no hurt: A man sitting on the Church beere, at the lower end of the Church, the beere was struck and torne, and the man throwne into a seat by the wall side, and had no hurt: a beame broke in the middle and fell betweene the minister and the clarke and hurt neither.

The Church was very much defased and torne, a great stone neere the foundation or the Church was torne out
and removed: stones were throwne from the Tower as thicke as if an hundred men had beene there throwing them, some of such waight and bignesse as no man was able to lift.

One of the Pinnacles of the Tower was throwne downe into the Church: the pillar against which the Pulpet standeth, being newly whited was made black: the roofe of the Church was tome, and a great part thereof broke into the Church: a bowlingalley neere the Churchyard was turned up into
pits and holes.

A little before night some went into the Church to fetch out the dead bodies, and found two little children walking hand in hand, and had no hurt, and seemed by their countenance to be nothing frighted.

The fearefull Iudgements and tokens of Gods wrath doe serve to admonish all, both men and women, young and old, poore and rich, of two things, first not to dare to appeare before God in their sinnes without repentance: secondly (when they are come
into his holy presence) to worship him reverently both in body and in Spirit without hipocrisie.

Also for as much as children, out of their parents sight, and servants out of their masters sight, doe trouble and offend many with their talking, laughing, and unreverent behaviour, wherewith they doe dishonour and provoke God to wrath, that therfore parents would sanctifie and prepare their children, and masters their servants, before they bring them to appeare before the Lord
their God, as God commanded Moses to sanctifie the people, and that the people should wash their clothes before they came to heare the Lord, when hee did publish the Law upon Mount Sinai: Exod. 19.
Q. 12. How did Moses sanctifie the people?

A. Moses did sanctifie them by praying to God for them, and by teaching them how to appeare before God, in true faith and repentance and how to behave themselves reverently, and to harken with holy
reverence unto the Lord speaking unto them; so ought parents to sanctifie their children, and masters their servants.
Qu. 13. Why did God command that the people should wash their clothes?

A. Sinne is a loathsome filthinesse in the sight of God, Mal. 2.15.20. Repentance is compared to washing and making cleane, Isa. 1.16. Ier. 7.3. The meaning of Almighty God, in commanding that the people should wash their cloaths was to shew that hee
would not have them to appeare before him in their sinnes, but would have them to repent them of their sinnes, and lead a new life, and give an outward signe and token thereof by appearing before him in cleane cloathes. Hence it is that the people of God have ever since put on cleane aloathes when they goe to the publique assembly to worship God.
Q. 14. What is this to us?

A. This serveth to teach us when wee put off our old, or foule
cloathes, to thinke upon our sinnes, wherewith wee have defiled our selves, and bee ashamed and afraid to appeare in our sinnes before God, on the Lords day, who dyed for our sinnes, and rose againe for our Iustification.
Q. 15. Why doth God begin the fourth Commandement with a memento; Remember the Sabboth day, which charge is not in any of the other Commandements?

A. God doth give his people charge to remember
the Sabboth day, to shew that hee doth make great reckoning of keeping it holy, and therefore would have his people to remember it before it comes, that they may prepare themselves and dispose of their affaires so, as they may attend the duties of the Sabboth.
Q 16. Is the Commandement laid upon all alike?

A. No, the greatest charge is laid upon parents that have children, and upon masters that
have servants.
Q. 17. Are Magistrates exempted?

A. No, the Magistrate above all is bound to obey and to have a care of the Sabboth, as Nehemiah had, chap. 13.14. For as the loadstone draweth iron, so the magistrates example doth draw the people: when Ieroboam forsooke the Law of the Lord, hee led away all Israell with him, 2 Chronicles 12. when Asa swore to seek the Lord, the people sought the Lord with him.
Q. 18. What reasons can you shew to move men to remember the Sabboth day to keepe it holy?
A. God himselfe setteth downe five strong reasons or arguments.
Q. 19. What is the first?
A. The first is drawn from the goodnesse of God in allowing us sixe dayes, and in reserving but one for himselfe.
Q. 20. What is the second?

A. The second is drawne from the authority
of God, to command, and power to punish such as will not obey as he is the Lord.
Q. 21. What is the third?

A. The third is in these words, Thy God, which may bee framed thus. The people with whom I have made a Covenant to bee their God, and have chosen to be my people ought to serve mee; but I have made a Covenant with you and have chosen you to bee my people, and have appointed the seventh day for my service:
therefore you ought to remember the seventh day to keepe it holy for my service.
Q. 22. What is the fourth?

The fourth is in these words, The Lord blessed the seventh Day, which may bee framed thus, the day that I, the Lord your God have blessed, that is, the day that I have appointed to bee a means to bring my blessing on them that doe remember it to keepe it holy, you ought to remember, to keepe holy: but the seventh day is
the day that I have appointed to bee a meanes to bring my blessing on them that doe remember it, to keepe it holy: therefore (as you desire my blessing) you ought to remember the seventh day to keepe it holy.
Q. 23. What is the fift.

A. The fift is in these words, and hallowed it, which may be thus framed, the day that I the Lord your God have hallowed, that is, set apart to bee kept holy, and that I have appointed to bee a means to sanctifie them,
that doe remember it to keepe it holy, ought to be remembred, and kept holy: but the seventh day is the day that I have set apart to be kept holy, and that I have appointed to bee a meanes to sanctifie them that do remember it to keepe it holy: therefore as you desire to bee Saints militant here upon earth, and Saints triumphant in Heaven for ever, remember the seventh day to keepe it holy.
Q. 24. What is it to keepe holy the seventh day?
A. To keepe holy the seventh day, is to rest upon it from our owne workes, wills, wayes, and words, and to spend it in holy exercises.
Q. 25. How ought we to rest?
A. The rest ought to bee first inward in the heart, from thinking, musing, and plodding upon worldly businesses, profits and carnall pleasures.
Q. 26. What are the things that wee ought to thinke upon on the seventh day?

A. For as much as the
seventh day is to be kept holy in honour of God the Father, wee ought therefore to thinke upon his holy Majesty, and upon his gooddesse towards us, in creating all things in heaven and in earth next to his owne glory to serve us, and us to serve him, and to praise him for the same. God is not as a Carpenter, that maketh an house for another body, and when he hath done takes no more care of it. God hath from the beginning and will to the end of the world, shew his eternall Wisedome, Power, Iustice,
Mercy, Truth Providence and Goodnesse, in preserving, governing and disposing of all things to his owne glory and good of his people: therefore wee ought to thinke and consider, that God is not only the Creator, but also the preserver, governor, and disposer of all things, and to praise him for the same.
Q. 27. What is our duty towards God, as hee is the Creator of all things?

A. Our duty is, to
acknowledge him to bee Lord and owner of all things, and for his sake have a care not to abuse, nor cruelly to handle any living creature, no not such as are hurtfull, and which wee may lawfully hurt and destroy; wee ought to shew mercy on them when they fall into our hands, by ridding them out of their lives as soone as we can, and not to sport our selves with tormenting them, as many hard hearted wretches do most cruelly: a thing unseemly in the children of God, that ought to be mercifull, as their Heavenly
father is mercifull.
Q 28. What is our duty towards God, as he is our Creator?
A. Our duty is, to be wel cōtented with that shape & proportiō of body, & faculty of soule wherein he hath created us.

They that are of a comly shape and proportion, and well favoured, ought not to beproud, nor loath scorne, nor mocke them that are deformed or ill favoured, but rather bee moved upon sight of them with thankefull hearts to praise God, for not making them so deformed,
and ill favoured.
Q. 29. What is our duty towards God as he is the preserver of all things?

A. Our duty is to take notice of his Wisedome, Power, Providence, and Goodnesse; and to praise him for the same, especially for his Goodnesse in preserving us from the houre that wee were borne till this houre, and for the hope that wee have that he will preserve us to eternall life, through Iesus Christ.

Q. 30. What is our duty towards God, as hee
is governour and disposer of all things?

A. Our duty is to bee ruled and governed by him, and to be well contented with that estate of life wherein it pleaseth his holy Majesty to place us, how meane soever it be, and patiently to beare whatsoever shall please his holy Majesty to lay upon us, either for our sinnes or for our triall.
These things we ought to think upon every day, especially on the Lords day.

Q. 31. What other things ought we to think
upon on the Lords day?

A. Wee ought with loving and thankefull hearts to think upon our Saviour Christ, and upon those things that he hath suffered and done for us, and therewith comfort our selves, and stirre up our hearts to rejoyce in him, and praise his holy and great name.

Also for as much as the seventh day was ordained for the publicke worship and service of God, we ought therefore to thinke upon the worship and service of God, and of the time of assembling therunto, and have
a care by holy meditations and prayer that God would prepare and make us fit to joyne with the congregation in that part of Gods worship that is then in hand; as, if the Minister bee reading, or preaching, wee ought then to hearken diligently with reverence, or if the Minister and people bee praying, and singing of Psalmes, we ought then presently to joyne with them.
Q. 32. What ought we chiefly to think upon during the time that we are in the publike assembly?
A. We ought then to thinke and consider, that we are in an heaven upon earth, and in the presence of the holy Trinity, and of the holy Angels and Saints militant.
Q. 33. Where doe you finde, that the place where God is truly worshipped here on earth, is called heaven?

A. In the twelfth chapter of the Revelation, the first, third, and seventh verses, mention is made of three greatwonders in heaven; the first is a Woman cloathed with the Sunne; the second
is a great red dragon, having seven heads and ten hornes, and seven crownes upon his head; the third is a battell fought in heaven betweene Michael and his Angels, and the Dragon and his Angels: by heaven there is meant, not the highest heaven, where God is in his Kingdome of glory, for there is no such Dragon, nor battell, therefore by heaven in that place is meant, the place where the true worshippers of God have their being, and doe assemble themselves to worship God publikely.
Q. 34 What is meant by the woman, and by the Sunne wherewith shee is clothed?

A. By the woman is meant the true Church of Christ, which is often in the Scriptures called his wife, and Spouse: by the Sunne is meant Iesus Christ. Mal. 4.2. whose righteousnesse imputed to them that doe truly repent and beleeve in him, doth serve as a garment wherewith their sinnes are covered and kept from rising up in Iudgement to condemne them.
Q. 35. What is meant by the Dragon?
A. By the Dragon is meant the Devill, in the persecuting heathen Emperours, and in Antichrist.
Q 36. What is meant by the battell?
A. By the battell is meant persecutions and warre raised by the heathen Emperors, and by Antichrist, against the Truth and professors thereof.

Q. 37. VVhere doe you finde that the holy Trinity, and the holy
Angels are in the place, where God is truly worshipped?

A. In the fourth chapter of the Revelation, and the second and third verses mention is made of a Throne in heaven, and of one sitting on the Throne: by heaven is meant the place where God is truly worshipped, by the Throne is meant the hearts and consciences of the true worshippers of God; he that sitteth on the Throne is the first Person in the holy Trinity, God the Father, whose admirable
glory and beauty is compared to two of the most pretious stones under the Sunne, a Jasper and a Sardine.
Q. 38. VVherein doth the glory and beauty of God shew it selfe unto the true worshippers?
A. The holy Word of God, when it is read, or preached is as a cleare christall glasse wherein they doe behold the glory and beauty of God to their unspeakeable joy.

Q. 39. VVhy are the hearts and consciences of the true worshippers
of God compared to a Throne or Chaire of State?

A. They are compared to a Throne or Chaire of State to shew that God who is the King of kings hath his dwelling and resting place in them, and that he as King doth rule and governe them by his Word and holy Spirit. Psal. 132.13.14.

Q. 40. Mention is made in the fourth ver. of twenty foure Elders sitting upon seates round about the Throne, clothed
in white rayment, having Crownes of gold upon their heads, what is meant by the twenty foure Elders?

A. The twenty foure Elders are the true worshippers of God, who are said to be twenty foure, because of the type that was of them in the Prophet David, who had foure and twenty thousand servants tending upon him monthly, 1 Chro. 27.1.

Q 41. VVhy are they said to be round about the Throne where God the
Father sitteth?

A. They are said to be round about the Throne toshew that they are neer & deer unto God & that they have God alwaies dwelling with them, according to his promise, 2 Cor. 6.26. even in the midst of them to defend them from all enemies, Zeph. 3 17.
Q. 42. VVhat is signified by their crownes of Gold.
A. Their crownes of Gold doe signifie, that Christ hath made them kings, chap. 1.6.
Q. 43. VVhat is signified by their white raiment?

A. Their white rayment signifieth the holinesse and righteousnesse of Christ imputed unto them. Also for as much as the Priests in the time of the Law did weare white linnen, therfore their white garments did signifie that Christ hath made them Priests to offer unto God the sacrifice of thankes and praise, as wee may gather out of their owne confession, chap. 5.10. Thou hast made us unto our God Kings and Priests, and we shall raigne on the earth meaning over sinne, so as it shall not have dominion
over them.
Q. 44. It is said in the fourth chapter, and latter end of the sixt verse, that there were foure beasts round about the Throne, what was signified by the beasts?
A. The foure beasts did signifie the faithfull preachers of the Gospell.
Q. 45. Why are they said to be foure?
A They are said to be foure, because they are to preach the Gospell in all the foure quarters of the world.

Q. 46. Why are they
said to be full of eyes, and to have each of them six wings, and that the first is like a Lyon, the second like a Calfe, and the third had a face like a man, and the fourth was like to a flying Eagle. chap. 4.6.7.8.

A. They are said to be full of eyes, to shew that they ought to bee as Job was, an eye to the blind and ignorant, Job 29.15. and to shew that they ought to be watchfull and full of knowledge, able to teach, exhort, rebuke, and convince.

They are said to have wings, to shew that they ought not to bee slow, but swift, and ready to minister a word in season, to strengthen the weake, to confirme the strong, to raise up the fallen, to bind up the broken hearted, to beate downe the lofty, to seeke what is lost, and to bring home the stray.

The first beast is said to bee like a Lyon, to shew that they ought to be full of godly courage and boldnesse: The second like a Calfe or Bullocke used to the yoke, to shew that they ought
to be full of patience, and willing to take paines: The third had a face like a man, to shew that they ought not to be as beasts, without understanding, but men of wisedome, judgement and discretion: The fourth is said to be like to an Eagle, to shew that as an Eagle doth soare aloft, and flye very high, so they ought not to bee covetous and earthly minded, but to have their conversation in heaven; and to set their mindes on heaven and heavenly things.

Q 47. It is written in
the seventh verse, that when the foure beasts gave glory, honour, and thankes to him that sate on the Throne, the twenty foure Elders did fall downe before him that sate on the Throne to worship him, and did cast downe their crownes before the Throne, shew the meaning of that?

A. The meaning is, that when (in the publike assembly) the minister doth either pray, or give thankes unto God, all the true worshippers of God doe then in heart joyne
with him, and (in acknowledgement of their unworthinesse) do humble and cast down themselves with holy reverence, humbly kneeling upon their knees, which is signified by casting downe their crownes.
Q. 48. It is written chap. 5.11.12. that many Angells were round about the Throne, and about the beasts and Elders, why are the Angels said to bee round about the Throne?

A. They are said to be round about the Throne
to shew that they are ready to attend and to obey the Commandements of the Lord Psal. 103.20. and round about the beasts and the Elders to shew, that they doe watch over the faithfull preachers and true worshippers of God. Psal. 34.7.
Q. 49. It is written chap. 5.6. that in the midst of the Throne, and of the foure beasts and Elders stood a Lamb, as though hee had beene kild?

A. By the Lambe is meant our Saviour Christ
the standing of the Lamb in the middest of the Throne (where God the Father sitteth) sheweth that our Saviour Christ is equall with God the Father in glory, Majesty, dignitie and power, to rule and govern the true worshippers of God, and to defend and protect them from all enemies; the standing of the Lamb in the midst of the foure beasts and Elders, sheweth that Christ is alwaies present with the true worshippers of God, both Minister and people, and hath a continuall care of them, chap. 2.1
The standing of the Lamb before the throne, as though hee had beene slaine, sheweth that the death and sufferings of Christ, are alwayes in fresh and continuall memorie with God, and that the continuall beholding of Christ doth move God to shew continuall mercie for his sake.
Q 50. It is written chap. 4.5. that there was seven lamps of fire burning before the throne which are the seven spirits of God, shew the meaning of that place?
A. By the seven lamps of fire wee are to understand the holy Ghost.
Q. 51. Why is the holy Ghost compared to lamps of fire burning?
A. Because it doth enlighten the hearts and minds of the true worshippers of God.
Q. 52. Why is the holy Ghost compared to seven lamps?

A. The number seven doth signifie fullnesse, or perfection, the holy Ghost is compared to seven lamps because of the fullnesse of light and saving knowledge and
grace that it worketh in the true worshippers of God.
Q. 53. Why is the holy Ghost called the seven Spirits of God?
A. It is called the seven spirits of God, because of the manifold spirituall graces that it worketh in the true worshippers.
Q. 54. It is written that out of the Throne proceeded lightning and thundring, and voices, what is signified by the lightning and thundring?
A. By the lightning and thundring is signified the powerful working of the holy Ghost in the hearts of the true worshippers, by the preaching of the law and of the Gospell.
Q. 55. VVhy is the preaching of the Law compared to Lightning?

A. It is compared to Lightning, to shew that as when Lightning commeth into a dark roome, it doth make things hid in darkenesse to be seene, so the preaching of the law by the illumination of the holy Ghost, doth
bring men that sit in darkenesse and shadow of death, to a sight of their sinnes, and of the wrath of God.
Q. 56. Why is the preaching of the Law compared to thundring?

A. It is compared to thundering because it doth thunder out the wrath and judgement of God that shall come on them that live and die in their sinnes without true faith and repentance, and so stirreth up them that stand in doubt of any thing, and would be further satisfied to goe to
the preacher and speake unto him as the Jewes did to Saint Peter when they were pricked in their hearts, Act. 2.37.
Q. 57. What ought we to doe, when the publique worship and service of God is ended?
A. Wee ought then presently to thinke upon the goodnesse of God in bringing us together to worship him in peace and safety from all enemies, and to give him hearty thankes.

Wee ought then also to think upon our weaknesse and failings in calling
upon God, in singing the Psalmes, and in harkning unto Gods holy Word read and preached unto us, and desire God for Christ his sake to forgive us.

Also in the way (as we are going home) from the Church, all children and servants, as well as parents and masters, ought to thinke upon the Word of God which was read and preached unto them, and meditate upon it while it is fresh in their memory.
Q. 58. What ought we to talke of on the Lords day?

A. Our chiefe talke ought to be of God, and of his workes, and word, and to confer of it with them that feare God. Mal. 3.16. and with our Minister, if wee doubt of any thing, Mal. 2.7. and not suffer any corrupt communication to proceed out of our mouthes, but such as may edifie and minister grace to the hearers. Eph. 4.29.
Q. 59. Is merry talking, jesting, and singing of merry songs a breach of the Lords day?

A. Yes, not onely in him that useth it, but also
in others, because it causeth them to draw their minds from holy meditations to hearken thereunto.
Q. 60. May not men reckon with their servants or labourers, and pay them their wages, and appoint them their worke on the Lords day?
A. No.
Q. 61. To pay labourers their wages is an almes deed, and therefore no breach of the Lords day?

A Labourers wages is no Almes, but a debt due
as soone as they have done their worke Levit. 10.13. Deut. 24.15.
Q. 65. What are the things that may be done on the Lords day?

A. Every worke of mercy and urgent necessity, such as could not be prevented not deferred to another time, as to resist the invasions of enemies, or robberies, to quench the rage of fire, to dresse meat, but not to make great dinners, because thereby men are made unfit for holy duties, and servants kept from going to Church.
Also to fodder Cattell, to pull a Sheep or any other living creature out of a pit.
In these and the like cases of necessity, a man may labour, but not for wages.
Q. 61. May not the Poore worke, and so earn something on the Lords Day?
A. No, for the Commandement is laid on the poore, as well as the rich

Q. 62. May not Chapmen, Higlers, and Carriers, carry commodities
out of the countrey into the City, and out of the City into the Countrey?
A. No, for that were to preferre the service of the City and of the Country before the Service of God.
